meanings.def: to put clothes, etc. into a bag in preparation for a trip away from home
examples: I haven't packed yet.
I have to start packing for my trip.
pack something I haven't packed my suitcase yet.
I packed my bags and left.
Did you pack the camera?
pack A with B He packed a bag with a few things and was off.
pack B into A He packed a few things into a bag.
pack somebody something I've packed you some food for the journey.

meanings.def: to put something into a container so that it can be stored, transported or sold
examples: pack something in/into something The pottery was packed in boxes and shipped to the US.
pack something up I carefully packed up the gifts.
pack something up in/into something Ryan busied himself packing everything up into bags.
pack something He found a part-time job packing eggs.

meanings.def: to protect something that breaks easily by surrounding it with soft material
examples: The paintings were carefully packed in newspaper.

meanings.def: to preserve food in a particular substance
examples: fish packed in ice

meanings.def: to fill something with a lot of people or things
examples: + adv./prep. We all packed together into one car.
pack something (with something) Fans packed the hall to see the band.
Pack wet shoes with newspaper to help them dry.

meanings.def: to press something such as snow or soil to form a thick hard mass
examples: Pack the earth down around the plant.
a patch of packed snow

meanings.def: to carry a gun
examples: to pack a gun
Is he packing?

meanings.def: to have something
examples: A storm packing 75 mph winds swept across the area last night.

meanings.def: to leave a person or place permanently, especially after an argument
to be capable of hitting somebody very hard
to have a powerful effect on somebody
examples: The advertising campaign packs quite a punch.

meanings.def: to tell somebody clearly or rudely to go away
examples: She tried to interfere but I sent her packing.

idioms.def: to leave a person or place permanently, especially after an argument
to be capable of hitting somebody very hard
examples: The advertising campaign packs quite a punch.

idioms.def: to tell somebody clearly or rudely to go away
examples: She tried to interfere but I sent her packing.

meanings.def: a container, usually made of paper, that holds a number of the same thing or an amount of something, ready to be sold
examples: pack of something a pack of cigarettes/gum
You can buy the envelopes in packs of ten.
a family pack (= one big enough for a family) of crisps

meanings.def: a set of different things that are supplied together for a particular purpose
examples: Send for your free information pack today.
a starter/welcome/gift pack
Each child was given a party pack filled with goodies.

meanings.def: a number of things that are wrapped or tied together, especially for carrying
examples: donkeys carrying packs of wool
(figurative) Everything she told us is a pack of lies (= a story that is completely false).

meanings.def: a large bag that you carry on your back
examples: We passed a group of walkers, carrying huge packs.
The water in his pack made it very heavy.

meanings.def: a group of animals that hunt together or are kept for hunting
examples: packs of savage dogs
wolves hunting in packs
a pack of hounds
the dominant animal in the pack

meanings.def: a group of similar people or things, especially one that you do not like or approve of
examples: We avoided a pack of journalists waiting outside.
He's the leader of the pack.
Of all the newspapers, this one is the worst of the pack.

meanings.def: all the people who are behind the leaders in a race, competition, etc.
examples: measures aimed at keeping the company ahead of the pack

meanings.def: a complete set of 52 playing cards
examples: a pack of cards
During the earthquake, buildings collapsed like a pack of cards.
Take a card from the top of the pack.

meanings.def: an organized group of cubs / Cub Scouts or brownies
examples: to join a Brownie pack

meanings.def: a hot or cold piece of soft material that holds liquid, used for treating a wound
a person or thing that could change the way that things will happen in a way that cannot be predicted

idioms.def: a person or thing that could change the way that things will happen in a way that cannot be predicted
